title: Porsche 547 engine
text:
The Porsche 547 and Porsche 547/3 are <a href="naturally-aspirated">naturally-aspirated</a>, <a href="Flat-four%20engine">flat-four</a>, <a href="boxer%20engine">boxer</a> <a href="motor%20racing">racing</a> <a href="internal%20combustion%20engine">engines</a>, designed by <a href="Porsche">Porsche</a> for <a href="Formula%20One%20racing">Formula One racing</a>; between and 
History.
In October 1958, the <a href="F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration%20Internationale%20de%20l%27Automobile">Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile</a> (FIA) announced that for the 1961 Formula One season, engine capacity would be limited to the same 1.5 litres as in <a href="Formula%20Two">Formula Two</a> (F2). This meant that Porsche could use their F2 cars almost unchanged in F1. The 787 would not get the eight-cylinder though, continuing with the air-cooled, <a href="Overhead%20camshaft%23Dual%20overhead%20camshaft">DOHC</a> four-cylinder Type 547 <a href="Flat%20engine%23Boxer%20engine">boxer engine</a> that had been developed by <a href="Ernst%20Fuhrmann">Ernst Fuhrmann</a> and that had powered the 550 Spyders and 718 series until then. It was powered by a 547/3 four-cylinder engine with Kugelfischer <a href="fuel%20injection">fuel injection</a>. At Monaco the car retired when the fuel injection cut out. A second car, also fitted with the 547/3 engine, was completed in time to appear in the Dutch Grand Prix on 22 May alongside the other 787.
